clean_content:
Asbestos

Terminology  

* Also called Ferruginous bodies

  
Epidemiology  

* Usually due to industrial / occupational exposure

  
Sites  

* Most common in thoracic / hilar lymph nodes* Concentration of asbestos fibers in lymph nodes is 2 - 3x higher than in lung

  
Clinical features  

* Inhaled asbestos fibers have iron protein mucopolysaccharide coating* Enlarged lymph nodes are common* Associated symptoms / signs of pulmonary asbestosis

  
Diagnosis  

* Biopsy of affected lymph node* Bleach digestion for confirmation

  
Radiology description  

* Mediastinal / hilar lymphadenopathy

  
Prognostic factors  

* Pulmonary asbestosis is a risk factor for lung carcinoma and mesothelioma

  
Case reports  

* 26 year old man with mesothelioma due to asbestos exposure ([Case Rep Med 2011;2011:951732](21776278))

  
Clinical images  
  
Images hosted on other servers:  
  
Asbestos with mesothelioma:  

[![Missing Image](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/thumb/lymphnodesasbestosbodiesradio1.jpg)](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3138115/figure/fig1/)

Enlarged supraclavicular node

[![Missing Image](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/thumb/lymphnodesasbestosbodiesradio2.jpg)](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3138115/figure/fig3/)

Epiphrenic node on right

[![Missing Image](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/thumb/lymphnodesasbestosbodiesradio3.jpg)](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3138115/figure/fig4/)

Node inside lesion

  
  
Gross description  

* Lymph nodes may be enlarged but show no significant abnormalities on cut surface

  
Microscopic (histologic) description  

* Asbestos bodies are golden-brown, beaded or dumbbell shaped structures with a thin, translucent core

  
Differential diagnosis  

* **Pseudoasbestos bodies*** **Other ferruginous bodies**

  
Additional references  

* [Am Rev Respir Dis 1990;142:843](2171386), [Environ Health Perspect 1994;102 Suppl 5:253](7882945), [Arch Pathol Lab Med 2010;134:462](20196674), [Thorax 1985;40:948](4095677), [Environ Health 2008;7:4](18218073), [Mod Pathol 1990;3:513](2217155), [Am J Ind Med 2000;37:169](10615097), [Clin Radiol 1992;45:340](1516346), [Am J Physiol Lung Cell Mol Physiol 2014;306:L170](24213921)

Gold

Definition / general  

* Colloidal gold is used for anti-tumor therapy, to treat autoimmune diseases and for drug delivery ([Wikipedia: Colloidal gold [Accessed 22 June 2018]](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Colloidal_gold))* Lymphadenopathy and lymph node infarction are uncommon complications of gold injections; occur via accumulation of gold particles in macrophages

  
Sites  

* Cervical, axillary, mesenteric lymph nodes, depending on route of administration

  
Clinical features  

* Tender enlarged lymph nodes* Benign process with resolution of symptoms on withdrawal of gold treatment

  
Diagnosis  

* Biopsy* Darkfield microscopy and autometallography methods demonstrate gold nanoparticles 15 to 50 nm

  
Laboratory  

* Polymorphonuclear neutrophilia, leukopenia, thrombocytopenia* Hepatic toxicity

  
Radiology description  

* Gold deposits can mimic intranodal axillary calcific deposits on mammography in patients with rheumatoid arthritis ([Proc (Bayl Univ Med Cent) 2013;26:28](23382606))

  
Case reports  

* 34 year old woman with lymphadenopathy and lymph node infarction ([J Clin Pathol 2001;54:562](11429432))* Intramammary lymph node gold deposits simulating microcalcifications on mammogram ([Hum Pathol 1988;19:992](3402989))* Lymphadenopathy and lymph node infarction ([Am J Med 1986;80:537](3082202))

  
Gross description  

* Extensive necrosis of lymph node

  
Microscopic (histologic) description  

* Subtotal or complete infarction with peripheral rim of organizing granulation tissue in region of subcapsular sinus* Small focus of residual viable lymphoid tissue has features of follicular hyperplasia* Center of node has ghost outlines of necrotic cells

  
Microscopic (histologic) images  
  
Images hosted on other servers:  

[![Missing Image](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/thumb/lymphnodesgoldmicro1.jpg)](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC1731461/figure/F1/)

Infarcted tissue

[![Missing Image](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/thumb/lymphnodesgoldmicro2.jpg)](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC1731461/figure/F2/)

Reticulin: preservation of nodal architecture

  
  
Positive stains  

* Immunohistochemical stains confirm the reactive nature of the process

  
Differential diagnosis  

* [Lymphoma](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/lymphoma.html)* Vascular thrombosis, infections and mechanical pressure can also cause infarction of lymph nodes

  
Additional references  

* [Russian Open Medical Journal 2013;2:1](http://www.researchgate.net/publication/257356072_Accumulation_and_Biodistribution_of_Gold_Nanoparticles_in_the_Mesenteric_Lymph_Nodes_at_Oral_Administration)

Iron

Definition / general

* Iron deposition in lymph nodes is rare* Also called hemosiderosis* May be associated with [hemochromatosis](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/liverhemochromatosis.html)

  
Sites

* Portal, splenic, mesenteric or axillary, depending on the primary cause

  
Pathophysiology

* Parenteral iron administration* Multiple transfusions: red blood cells are lysed and iron is deposited in macrophages in the liver and spleen followed by drainage to adjacent lymph nodes* Hereditary hemosiderosis: abnormalities in iron transport - most common is *HFE1* gene mutation; also mutations in *TfR2, HJV, HAMP*, ferroportin-V162del ([Hepatology 2005;42:466](15986403))* Anemia of inflammation: associated with rheumatoid arthritis, gout ([Ann Rheum Dis 1970;29:81](5416103))

  
Clinical features

* Depends on the primary cause* Enlarged lymph nodes

  
Diagnosis

* Biopsy with Perls Prussian blue stain

  
Radiology description

* CT: enlarged and hyperdense lymph nodes ([AJR Am J Roentgenol 1981;136:1191](6786034))

  
Prognostic factors

* Depends on the primary cause, severity and extent of the disease

  
Case reports

* Women, 19 to 49 years, with lymphadenopathy after single infusion of iron dextran ([J Clin Pathol 1968;21:492](5697350))

  
Treatment

* Reduce iron overload, treat the primary cause

  
Gross description

* Enlarged lymph nodes

  
Gross images  
  
Images hosted on other servers:  

[![Missing Image](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/thumb/lymphnodesiron_upmc02.jpg)](http://path.upmc.edu/cases/case77/images/gross1.jpg)

Lymph nodes at bottom right

  
  
Microscopic (histologic) description

* Follicular hyperplasia, sinus histiocytosis, golden brown pigment deposition

  
Microscopic (histologic) images  
  
Contributed by Mark R. Wick, M.D.  

[![Missing Image](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/wick/hemosiderosis%20lymph%20node%20in%20sickle%20cell%20disease%20perls%20iron%20s.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/wick/hemosiderosis%20lymph%20node%20in%20sickle%20cell%20disease%20perls%20iron%20s.jpg)

In sickle cell disease

  
  
Positive stains

* [Perls prussian blue](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsiron.html)

  
Negative stains

* [Melanin stains](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsfontana.html)

  
Electron microscopy description

* Prominent phagocytic reticulum cells containing vacuoles, myelin figures, lipid droplets and very large lysosomal bodies with fine electron dense granules concentrated in these lysosomal bodies and in the cytoplasm, which show molecular structure of ferritin

  
Differential diagnosis

* **Charcoal laden macrophages*** **Hemazoin pigment:** seen in malaria* **Melanin pigment deposition:** [melanoma](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/lymphnodesmetastases.html#melanoma), [dermatopathic lymphadenitis](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/lymphnodesdermatopathiclymphadenitis.html)* [Tattoo pigment](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/skinnontumortattoo.html)

  
Additional references

* [Histopathology 2013;62:481](23278862), [Gastrointest Radiol 1989;14:59](2910746)

Lipogranuloma

Definition / general  

* Also called lipophagic granuloma* Secondary to various inflammatory and neoplastic conditions or primary lesion of lymph node* In West, commonly due to mineral oil ingestion or total parenteral nutrition

  
Case reports  

* 27 year old woman with prior giant cell tumor ([Acta Cytol 2002;46:772](12146051))

  
Microscopic (histologic) description  

* Giant cells (mono or multinuclear) with foamy and vacuolated cytoplasm

Melanosis

Definition / general

* A rare manifestation of a completely regressed melanoma

  
Terminology

* Tumoral melanosis* Nodular melanosis* Nodal melanosis

  
Epidemiology

* Very rare in lymph nodes

  
Sites

* Sentinel lymph nodes of regressed melanoma* Mesenteric lymph nodes

  
Pathophysiology

* Possibilities include:
  + A regressed focus of metastatic melanoma+ Melanophages migrating to the lymph node from the primary lesion

  
Clinical features

* Enlarged lymph nodes* Yellow brown spindle bodies in mesenteric nodes may be due to melanosis coli ([Histopathology 1978;2:47](208951))* The paucity of cases precludes adequate evaluation of long term implications and treatment outcomes

  
Case reports

* 36 year old man with lymph node melanosis and metastatic melanoma of unknown primary ([Arch Pathol Lab Med 2009;133:1332](19653733))* 83 year old man with melanosis coli involving pericolonic lymph nodes associated with the herbal laxative Swiss Kriss ([Arch Pathol Lab Med 2004;128:565](15086301))* Tumoral melanosis involving the sentinel lymph nodes ([J Cutan Pathol 2007;34:284](17302615))* Lymph node melanosis from a primary cutaneous lesion combining a nodular (tumoral) melanosis and a congenital dermal melanocytic nevus ([Am J Dermatopathol 2012;34:653](22456514))

  
Gross description

* Enlarged lymph nodes with or without brown pigment deposition

  
Microscopic (histologic) description

* Subcapsular and sinusoidal accumulation of pigmented cells with vesicular chromatin and inconspicuous nucleoli* Cells may be spindle shaped or epithelioid

  
Microscopic (histologic) images  
  
Images hosted on other servers:  

[![Missing Image](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/thumb/lymphnodesmelanosiscoli_nih01.png)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/17883860/#&gid=article-figures&pid=figure-2-uid-1)

Melanosis coli in a pericolonic lymph node

  
  
Positive stains

* [CD68](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/cdmarkerscd68.html)

  
Negative stains

* [S100](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainss100.html), [HMB45](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainshmb45.html) and [MelanA](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsmart1.html)

  
Differential diagnosis

* [Metastatic melanoma](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/lymphnodesmetastases.html#melanoma)

  
Additional references

* [Ioachim: Ioachim's Lymph Node Pathology, 4th Edition, 2008](http://www.amazon.com/exec/obidos/ASIN/0781775965/pathologyoutl-20)

Prosthesis related

Definition / general  

* See also [silicone](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/lymphnodessiliconeimplant.html)* May be an incidental finding at radical prostatectomy ([J Clin Pathol 2002;55:623](12147660))

  
Case reports  

* 76 year old woman with histiocytic lymphadenitis post shoulder joint replacement ([Am J Clin Pathol 1993;99:314](8447293))* 78 year old woman with right pelvic cystic mass due to chromium in hip prosthesis ([Acta Cytol 2003;47:270](12685200))* Post hip replacement with coexisting metastatic prostate adenocarcinoma to same lymph node ([Hum Pathol 1998;29:95](9445141))

  
Microscopic (histologic) description  

* Sinuses distended by large macrophages with abundant granular PAS+ eosinophilic cytoplasm representing polyethylene ([Am J Surg Pathol 1989;13:1050](2596617))* May contain black specks which resemble "dirt"* Pelvic lymph nodes in patients with cobalt chromium or titanium hip implants may have heavy metal microparticles or polyethylene particles with associated florid sinus histiocytosis ([Am J Surg Pathol 1994;18:83](8279630))

  
Microscopic (histologic) images  
  
*Images hosted on other servers:*  

[![Missing Image](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/thumb/lymphnodesprosthesismicro1.jpg)](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC1769730/figure/f1/)

Sinus histiocytosis

  
  
Positive stains  

* [PAS](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainspas.html)+ polyethylene particles

  
Electron microscopy images  
  
Images hosted on other servers:  

[![Missing Image](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/thumb/lymphnodesprosthesisemi1.jpg)](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC1769730/figure/f2/)

Particles are 1 micron

  
  
Differential diagnosis  

* [Metastatic melanoma](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/lymphnodesmetastases.html#melanoma) ([J Surg Oncol 1995;60:128](7564379))
